Literature Review: Clonal hematopoiesis, a phenomenon characterized by the expansion of a single hematopoietic stem cell clone due to acquired mutations, has emerged as a significant factor in aging and disease. This process, often referred to as clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), is increasingly recognized for its implications in both malignant and nonmalignant conditions. The association between clonal hematopoiesis and an elevated risk of hematologic malignancies, such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML), is well-documented. This risk is attributed to the accumulation of additional mutations in the clonal population, leading to malignant transformation (Jaiswal et al., 2014). Beyond its oncogenic potential, clonal hematopoiesis has been linked to an increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CAD), suggesting a broader impact on human health. The underlying mechanisms may involve pro-inflammatory cytokines released by mutated immune cells, which contribute to vascular inflammation and atherosclerosis (Fuster et al., 2017). Recent studies have identified several factors that influence the clinical outcomes of individuals with clonal hematopoiesis. These include the size of the mutant clone, the specific driver genes involved, and markers of epigenetic aging, such as DNA methylation patterns (Genovese et al., 2014; Xie et al., 2014). The size of the clone, in particular, has been shown to correlate with the risk of progression to hematologic malignancies and the severity of cardiovascular disease (Steensma et al., 2015). Additionally, the nature of the mutated genes plays a critical role in determining the trajectory of clonal expansion and its health implications. For example, mutations in DNMT3A, TET2, and ASXL1 are among the most commonly observed in clonal hematopoiesis and have been associated with distinct clinical outcomes (Jaiswal et al., 2017). Epigenetic aging, as measured by DNA methylation clocks, has also been implicated in the progression of clonal hematopoiesis, suggesting that epigenetic modifications may influence the fitness and expansion potential of mutant clones (Horvath, 2013). While clonal hematopoiesis is largely a consequence of aging, emerging evidence indicates that inherited genetic variation can modulate this process. Certain genetic polymorphisms have been associated with an increased propensity for clonal expansion, highlighting the interplay between inherited and acquired factors in the development of clonal hematopoiesis (Zink et al., 2017). This complex interplay underscores the importance of a comprehensive approach to understanding and managing clonal hematopoiesis, encompassing genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors. In conclusion, clonal hematopoiesis represents a critical intersection of aging, genetics, and disease. Its impact on human health extends beyond the risk of malignancy to include significant contributions to cardiovascular disease and possibly other age-related conditions. As our understanding of the molecular and genetic underpinnings of clonal hematopoiesis continues to evolve, so too will the opportunities for targeted interventions aimed at mitigating its adverse health effects.
